profileText: A Representative from Delaware; born at Bohemia Manor, Cecil County, Md., December 10, 1795; attended Wilmington Academy and St. Mary's College, Baltimore, Md., and was graduated from Princeton College in 1814; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in New Castle County, Del., in 1818; elected as an Anti-Jacksonian to the Twenty-second, Twenty-third, and Twenty-fourth Congresses, and reelected as a Whig to the Twenty-fifth Congress (March 4, 1831-March 3, 1839); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1838 to the Twenty-sixth Congress; appointed judge of the state superior court on September 19, 1839, and served until September 16, 1864, when he resigned; died in Philadelphia, Pa., April 20, 1875; interment in Wilmington and Brandywine Cemetery, Wilmington, Del.

researchRecord.name: 1813-1837. 1/8 foot. In the John J. Milligan papers and the William P. Brobson papers.
researchRecord.description: Personal, business, and congressional papers and correspondence, including 11 letters received from family and friends and 20 letters to Brobson. Finding aid in repository.

researchRecord.name: Biographical information in the Charles Lanman collection, 1787-1906.
